docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration promised relief today to millions of workers with aching backs, crippled fingers, sore wrists and other physical problems caused or aggravated by their jobs. The Labor Department took the first formal step to require employers to redesign jobs and alter work stations to accommodate workers suffering from injuries to the neck, back, arms and hands, and to help prevent such injuries. It made public a draft of proposed rules and said a final regulation, with the force of law, would be issued late next year after an extended period of public comment.

headline.main: Labor Department Acts to Stem Epidemic of Job-Related Aches

docs.abstract: Labor Dept takes first formal step to require employers to redesign jobs and alter work stations to accommodate workers suffering from injuries to neck, back, arms and hands, and to help prevent such injuries; makes public draft of proposed rules and says final regulation, with force of law, will be issued late next year; proposal is intended to alleviate epidemic of occupational injury and illness in factories and offices that accounts for one-third of all serious workplace injuries and over 640,000 workers a year to miss time on job (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Admiral Says More Money Is Needed for Embassies Adm. William J. Crowe, the retired Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who led a State Department investigation into the bombings of two American embassies in Africa last summer, said the department's fear of demanding additional money from Congress could leave more embassies vulnerable to attack. Admiral Crowe, a former Ambassador to London, also said the security budget requested by the State Department this month was inadequate. A1 Rebel's Arrest Unites Kurds Political divisions have long undermined the scattered Kurds in their battle for a homeland. But for the overwhelming majority of the estimated 850,000 Kurds now living in Europe, the arrest of the rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan has constituted a moment when differences are swept away, however fleetingly, by a shared sense of outrage. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: A state judge sternly directed New Jersey insurance regulators today to ''go back to the drawing board'' to insure continuity of health coverage for members of the insolvent HIP Health Plans of New Jersey as the state moves toward closing down the company by March 31. ''The problem with your plan is that it is no plan,'' Superior Court Judge Jack L. Lintner in Middlesex County said as he rebuked state officials and a deputy Attorney General, Josh Lichtblau, for giving him only verbal assurances that there would be no transition problems for HIP's 165,000 policyholders. ''You are going to be required to give me a complete plan by this Friday.''

headline.main: Judge Assails Trenton Plan for Failed H.M.O.

docs.abstract: Superior Court Judge Jack L Lintner orders New Jersey insurance regulators to devise plan to insure continuity of health coverage for members of insolvent HIP Health Plans of New Jersey as state moves toward closing company by Mar 31; scores state officials and Deputy Atty Gen Josh Lichtblau for giving him only verbal assurances that there will be no transition problems for 165,000 policyholders; cites shortcomings in interim plan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The $51.5 million judgment against Philip Morris Companies by a California jury surely puts private lawsuits against big tobacco companies back on the front burner (front page, Feb. 12). However, instead of bogging down the courts and filling the pockets of lawyers, there is a much simpler solution to make those who profit pay.

headline.main: Why Bog Down the Courts With Tobacco Suits?

docs.abstract: Michael Lowery Tracy letter, commenting on February 12 article on $51.5 million judgment against Philip Morris Cos by California jury in private lawsuit, suggests that smokers should join free of charge private health care and disability plans of tobacco companies; says it is simpler solution to make those who profit from cigatettes pay and would avoid bogging courts down with suits

docs.lead_paragraph: A local branch of the French national health insurance program said today that it was preparing a suit against four tobacco companies for up to $90 million, blaming them for smoking-related diseases. The lawsuit would be a first in France, where smoking remains widely tolerated and socially acceptable. The social security office in this coastal city will sue the Philip Morris Companies, Rothmans UK Holdings Ltd., Reynolds, which is a unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, and the French company Seita S.A.

headline.main: French Agency to Sue Tobacco Concerns

docs.abstract: Saint-Nazaire branch of French national health insurance program is preparing suit against four tobacco companies: Philip Morris Companies, Rothmans UK Holdings, Reynolds, which is unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp, and Seita SA; will seek up to $90 million for smoking-related diseases; lawsuit would be first in France, where smoking remains widely tolerated and socially acceptable (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IS there anyone who is not sick of hearing about Viagra? Since it was introduced last April, Pfizer's tiny blue impotence pill has popped up virtually everywhere, from the cover of Time magazine to the late-night lingo of Leno and Letterman. Even Bob and Elizabeth Dole, not ones to babble the family gossip in front of a national audience, were so amazed at Viagra's powers that they appeared separately on ''Larry King Live'' to tell the world about it. With such testimonials -- the Internet had the best, including the story of a man who had an erection that lasted several hours -- it was no wonder that Viagra became one of the most successful drugs ever introduced in the United States. By late December, some 7.5 million prescriptions had been written, enough to boost Viagra's worldwide sales to $788 million.

headline.main: What We've Learned From Those Little Blue Pills

docs.abstract: Comment on marketing lessons that Viagra, the male wonder drug, has taught drug industry about male attitudes toward medicine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF scientists invented a test that could almost eliminate the third most lethal form of cancer -- and if that test was time-consuming, expensive and really, really unpleasant -- you would have the vexing situation for men regarding colon cancer. The test is the colonoscopy. This scope-type test, along with its sibling, the sigmoidoscopy, has the potential to practically wipe out colorectal cancer, which killed 27,900 men last year.

headline.main: It's No Fun, but It May Save Your Life

docs.abstract: Advice on having colonoscopy, screening test that is unpleasant but has potential to practically wipe out colorectal cancer(S)

docs.lead_paragraph: CNN News Group, a unit of Time Warner Inc., said today that it had invested an undisclosed amount in the closely held Web MD and signed an agreement to exchange news and advertising with the company, an on-line medical information service. Financial details were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Web MD committed itself to a three-year, multimillion-dollar ad campaign across six CNN cable television networks. Web MD will be promoted on CNN Web sites, television and radio. CNN will use information from Web MD's Internet site, including health news and reports on medical research.

headline.main: Health Web Site Makes CNN Deal

docs.lead_paragraph: With their supporters among Republican moderates likely to play a more forceful role in the new Congress, union leaders who are gathered here for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s winter meeting predicted today that labor would make substantial gains this year in advancing its legislative wish list. The labor leaders say the narrowing of the Republican majority in the House to five votes will give their pet proposals, including a higher minimum wage and a patients' bill of rights, a better chance than in the two previous Congresses since the Republicans took control in the 1994 elections.

headline.main: Political Landscape Altered, Labor Sees Gains for Its Agenda

docs.abstract: Labor leaders gather in Miami Beach for AFL-CIO's winter meeting; with their supporters among Republican moderates in Congress likely to play more forceful role in new Congress, they predict labor will make substantial gains in 1999 in advancing its legislative wish list; say narropwing of Republican majority in House to five votes will give pet proposals better chance than in two previous Congresses since republicans took control in 1994 elections (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, which will be held tomorrow, instead of the usual Monday, because of the Presidents' Day holiday today.

headline.main: Treasury Sales List Is Confined to Bills
